article.title: Identification of therapeutic targets for chronic kidney disease through Mendelian randomization analysis of druggable genes
funding: Natural Science Foundation of Guangdong Province
Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Autophagy and Major Chronic Non-communicable Diseases
Discipline Construction Project of Guangdong Medical University
Zhanjiang City Science and Technology Development Special Funds Competitive Allocation Project
National Clinical Key Specialty Construction Project
The Affiliated Hospital of Guangdong Medical University
article.abstract: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a multifaceted and gradually advancing condition characterized by a complex pathogenesis. The current therapeutic options for CKD remain limited in efficacy. Consequently, the identification and exploration of novel drug targets for CKD are of paramount importance.

sections.introduction: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a progressive condition affecting over 800 million individuals globally. It is defined by a persistent estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of less than 60 mL/min/1.73 mÂ² body surface area, or urinary albumin excretion equal to or greater than 30 mg/day, or both, sustained for a duration exceeding three months.
sections.methods: In this MR analysis, we selected cis-expression quantitative trait loci (cis-eQTL) of druggable genes as the exposure variable and employed genome-wide association study (GWAS) data for CKD from the FinnGen database as the outcome variable.
sections.results: We employed the IVW method as the primary analytical approach. Sixteen druggable genes exhibited a strong association with the development of CKD at a FDR of less than 0.05.
sections.discussion: In this study, we found that the expression of 12 genes was closely related to CKD. For genes demonstrating significant associations in the MR analysis, we performed a comprehensive suite of sensitivity analyses and functional assessments.

article.insights_summary: This study identifies potential therapeutic targets for chronic kidney disease through Mendelian randomization analysis of druggable genes. The results suggest that TUBB may serve as a potential target for reducing CKD risk.
